title: NCP on ARPANET
overview: The Network Control Program (NCP) provides the first host-to-host protocol on ARPANET, paving the way for later TCP/IP standardization.

title: TCP/IP Concept Proposed
overview: Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn outline a transmission control and internet protocol architecture to interconnect heterogeneous networks—foundations of the modern Internet.

title: RFC 768 — UDP
overview: User Datagram Protocol formalized as a lightweight, connectionless transport for latency-sensitive traffic and simple message exchange.

title: RFC 791 — IPv4
overview: Internet Protocol version 4 standardized, defining addressing, fragmentation, and routing semantics that dominate for decades.

title: RFC 792 — ICMP
overview: Internet Control Message Protocol standardized to carry diagnostics and error reporting (e.g., echo/ping, unreachable).

title: RFC 793 — TCP
overview: Transmission Control Protocol standardized to provide reliable, ordered byte streams atop IP, enabling robust applications and services.

title: ARPANET TCP/IP Flag Day
overview: ARPANET officially migrates from NCP to TCP/IP, marking the Internet’s operational birth as an internetwork.

title: DNS Design (RFC 1034/1035)
overview: The Domain Name System replaces HOSTS.TXT with a scalable, distributed naming hierarchy and query protocol.

title: RFC 1058 — RIP
overview: Routing Information Protocol standardized for distance-vector routing in early IP networks and enterprise LANs.

title: RFC 1122 — Host Requirements
overview: Baseline requirements for Internet hosts documented, aligning TCP/IP implementations across vendors and OSes.

title: RFC 1191 — Path MTU Discovery
overview: PMTUD defined to determine the maximum transmission unit along a path, reducing IP fragmentation and improving performance.

title: RFC 1323 — TCP Extensions
overview: High-performance TCP extensions (timestamps, window scaling, PAWS) standardized to improve throughput on fast/long-fat networks.

title: RFC 1631 — NAT
overview: Network Address Translation introduced to alleviate IPv4 scarcity, enabling private networks to share public addresses.

title: RFC 1519 — CIDR
overview: Classless Inter-Domain Routing replaces classful addressing, enabling route aggregation and slowing global routing table growth.

title: RFC 1918 — Private IPv4 Addressing
overview: Non-routed private IPv4 blocks reserved for internal networks, becoming ubiquitous with NAT and home/enterprise gateways.

title: RFC 2131 — DHCP
overview: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol standardized for automatic IP configuration—addresses, gateways, DNS—for clients at scale.

title: IPng Selected (Toward IPv6)
overview: IETF selects IP next generation (IPng) direction to overcome IPv4 exhaustion and improve extensibility—setting the stage for IPv6.

title: 6bone IPv6 Testbed
overview: A global experimental IPv6 network (6bone) launches to test interoperability, transition tools, and early deployment practices.

title: RFC 2460 — IPv6 Specification
overview: Internet Protocol version 6 initially specified, expanding address space and simplifying header processing versus IPv4.

title: RFC 4271 — BGP-4
overview: Border Gateway Protocol version 4 documented as the Internet’s interdomain routing standard, supporting CIDR and policy control.

title: World IPv6 Launch
overview: Major ISPs, websites, and vendors permanently enable IPv6, moving beyond trials to mainstream dual-stack operation globally.

title: RFC 8200 — IPv6 Becomes Internet Standard
overview: IPv6 is elevated from Draft to Internet Standard, superseding RFC 2460 and reflecting maturity across deployments and vendors.

title: RFC 8484 — DNS over HTTPS (DoH)
overview: DNS queries can be sent over HTTPS to improve privacy and integrity between clients and resolvers, changing resolver ecosystems.

title: RFC 9000 — QUIC Transport
overview: QUIC standardized as a secure, multiplexed transport over UDP, reducing latency and ossification in the web transport layer.
